data.text: Training expected to produce a specific character or pattern of behavior, especially training that produces moral or mental improvement.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: was raised in the strictest discipline.

data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Control obtained by enforcing compliance or order.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Controlled behavior resulting from disciplinary training; self-control.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: Dieting takes a lot of discipline.

data.text: A state of order based on submission to rules and authority.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: a teacher who demanded discipline in the classroom.

data.text: Punishment intended to correct or train.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A set of rules or methods, as those regulating the practice of a church or monastic order.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A branch of knowledge or teaching.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To train by instruction and practice, as in following rules or developing self-control: synonym: teach.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: The sergeant disciplined the recruits to become soldiers.

data.text: To punish in order to gain control or enforce obedience. synonym: punish.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
